marklogic.body:
Michael - In your last sentence you say that "all of this boiling and roasting is going to happen on Earth anyhow in a couple million years when the sun naturally gets brighter". Are you sure you don't you mean a couple of billion years? As I understand it, the sun has about another 5 billion years to go before it engulfs us as a red giant and 2 million years seems a very small step along the way. I had assumed that, without our intervention through the Burning of fossil fuels, life on Earth would have at least another billion years to run.
I recently attempted a calculation on how long it would take for the oceans to boil away. The answer came out at something like 100,000 years, assuming an ongoing imbalance of 1% between solar radiation hitting Earth and re-radiation. If my answer is in the right order of magnitude (my proneness to error is legendary) then even with your 2 million year horizon, we would be bringing life on Earth to a very premature end.
Incidentally, where did you get your 1400C from? I thought the temperature on Venus was 460C, though I think I would personally find the difference between those temperatures to be largely of academic interest.
